author: Dinakar Peri
text:
The Defence Ministry on Friday cleared the purchase of air defence guns for the Air Force while decisions related to the new Defence Procurement Procedure (DPP) have been deferred to the next meeting likely to be held soon.

The Defence Acquisition Council chaired by Defence Minister Manohar Parrikar gave the Acceptance of Necessity for 61 flights of air defence guns for the Air Force, with each flight consisting of four guns, expected to cost Rs. 7,000 crore under the ‘Buy and Make’ procedure of the DPP.

“It is an integrated system with radars and capable of shooting down small radar cross section targets like drones and low flying objects,” a senior official said.

The AON is the first step in initiating the procurement process and now the IAF will issue a Request for Information (RFI) detailing the specifications. The process will now be initiated and the guns will be made in India with foreign collaboration.

The DAC also cleared the purchase of sensors and weapons package for the seven new stealth frigates (P-17A) to be built by Garden Reach Shipbuilders and Engineers (GRSE) and Mazagon Docks Limited (MDL).

A senior officer said that the DAC accorded approval “for procurement on single vendor basis as they are already being used by the Navy.”

While the new DPP has been discussed approvals to some changes like blacklisting procedures and strategic partnerships will be decided in the next meeting which will be held within this month, officials said. The major changes in the new DPP have already cleared and it is expected to be released in April.

title: DAC clears air defence guns for Indian Air Force
